ice-and-snc-lavalin/snc_lavalin.jpg","width":605,"height":362,"scalefactor":50},{"url":"https://images.thestar.com/CuhSPVard0xACmw6Q6yj2B_pVI4=/480x287/smart/filters:cb(1565823513730)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2019/08/14/ethics-report-reveals-close-co-ordination-between-trudeaus-office-and-snc-lavalin/snc_lavalin.jpg","width":480,"height":287,"scalefactor":40},{"url":"https://images.thestar.com/xhzjKrAktCkSVUIVR_BpXwwo0wo=/400x239/smart/filters:cb(1565823513730)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2019/08/14/ethics-report-reveals-close-co-ordination-between-trudeaus-office-and-snc-lavalin/snc_lavalin.jpg","width":400,"height":239,"scalefactor":33},{"url":"https://images.thestar.com/3kXApLrSNyvmX4XBMFnJ7-sobdM=/320x191/smart/filters:cb(1565823513730)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2019/08/14/ethics-report-reveals-close-co-ordination-between-trudeaus-office-and-snc-lavalin/snc_lavalin.jpg","width":320,"height":191,"scalefactor":27},{"url":"https://images.thestar.com/HEZt_3DR-8n-kDOnZkfL2x418kk=/93x56/smart/filters:cb(1565823513730)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/canada/2019/08/14/ethics-report-reveals-close-co-ordination-between-trudeaus-office-and-snc-lavalin/snc_lavalin.jpg","width":93,"height":56,"scalefactor":8}],"isLandscape":true}},{"text":"Dion’s investigation, which ruled Trudeau broke the conflict of interest law for the second time, found a senior adviser to the prime minister had been engaged on the question of offering a “deferred prosecution agreement” to SNC-Lavalin since 2016. ","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"type":"ad","heading":"ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW","name":"ArticleFirstBigBox","display":"medium-down","pos":"1","interstitial":true,"sizes":[[300,250]]},{"text":"A deferred prosecution agreement, also called a “remediation agreement” in Dion’s report, would allow SNC-Lavalin to avoid a criminal trial into fraud and bribery allegations — and a 10-year ban on federal contracts, should the company be convicted — in exchange for a monetary penalty and corporate reforms.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"The company also floated the idea of deferred prosecution agreements with Finance Minister Bill Morneau, a month before his 2018 budget bill amended the Criminal Code to allow them.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"Below is a select timeline of interactions between senior political staff in the Trudeau government and SNC-Lavalin executives and lawyers.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"<ul><li><strong>Early 2016</strong></li></ul>","type":"text","isParagraph":false},{"type":"ad","heading":"ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW","name":"ArticleSecondBigBox","display":"medium-down","pos":"2","interstitial":true,"sizes":[[300,250]]},{"text":"Trudeau and a senior adviser, Mathieu Bouchard, met with SNC-Lavalin’s CEO and senior representatives. According to Trudeau, the company discussed the consequences of a criminal conviction on the company. Trudeau testified that he instructed Bouchard to look into “remediation agreements” and how other countries handle similar situations, and tasked Bouchard with staying on top of the SNC-Lavalin file. ","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"type":"articleRelatedInlinePrimary"},{"type":"textBreakPoint","insertAt":"contentMiddleBreakPoint"},{"text":"<ul><li><strong>Sept. 25 to Nov. 17, 2017</strong></li></ul>","type":"text","isParagraph":false},{"text":"The federal government holds public consultations on legal tools for dealing with corporate wrongdoing.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"<strong>Jan. 23, 2018</strong>","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"SNC-Lavalin requests a meeting between CEO Neil Bruce and Morneau at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland. Morneau and his policy adviser, Justin To, met with Bruce and the issue of “remediation agreements” came up. According to To, Bruce warned of “negative economic impacts” if the company couldn’t reach a deal.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"type":"slimcut"},{"text":"<ul><li><strong>Feb. 2, 2018</strong></li></ul>","type":"text","isParagraph":false},{"text":"Bruce and other SNC-Lavalin representatives met with To in Ottawa, as a followup to the Davos meeting. From Dion’s report:","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"type":"ad","heading":"ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW","name":"ArticleThirdBigBox","display":"medium-down","pos":"3","interstitial":true,"sizes":[[300,250]]},{"text":"“The company presented Mr. To with a confidential discussion document outlining reasons in support of a remediation agreement regime and the company’s request for timely implementation of a regime via the federal budget. According to the document, this strategy would increase the likelihood of a settlement of the company’s pending criminal charges, of the company maintaining its head office in Canada for the foreseeable future and of an increase in its workforce.”","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"<ul><li><strong>Feb. 22, 2018</strong></li></ul>","type":"text","isParagraph":false},{"type":"articleRelatedInlineSecondary"},{"text":"The federal government releases the results of a public consultation on deferred prosecution agreements, which found that the majority of respondents supported the idea. Five days later, Morneau’s omnibus budget bill included amendments to the Criminal Code to allow for deferred prosecution agreements.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"<ul><li><strong>March, 2018</strong></li></ul>","type":"text","isParagraph":false},{"text":"Trudeau receives a memo from the Privy Council Office, the central agency that supports the prime minister, stating that SNC-Lavalin told federal officials it has a “Plan B” if the government did not bring in deferred prosecution agreements. According to Dion’s report, SNC’s “Plan B” involved splitting up the company and moving parts of SNC-Lavalin Group to another jurisdiction.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"type":"cta","buttonText":"Sign Up Now","buttonLink":"/emails.html?nsrc=article-inline-firstup-generic","description":"Start your morning with everything you need to know, and nothing you don't. Sign up for First Up, the Star's new daily email newsletter.","title":"Get more of what matters in your inbox"},{"text":"<ul><li><strong>November 2018</strong></li></ul>","type":"text","isParagraph":false},{"type":"textBreakPoint","insertAt":"contentLongBreakPoint"},{"text":"Dion’s report said SNC-Lavalin’s lawyers and representatives began to increase their “communications with government officials and staff in the Prime Minister’s Office with a view to finding solutions to override the Director of Public Prosecutions’ (DPP) decision.”","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"“(Staff) in the Prime Minister’s Office were told that the company’s board of directors was close to escalating measures in respect of their ‘Plan B,’” the report noted.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"Around the same time, Morneau and then-Treasury Board president Scott Brison met with Kevin Lynch, a former top bureaucrat now working with SNC, at a conference in Beijing, China. According to Morneau and Brison, the conversation was brief but focused on the Director of Public Prosecutions’ decision to not negotiate a deal. SNC told Dion that Lynch also floated the idea of third-party legal experts to provide advice to then-attorney general Jody Wilson-Raybould on remediation agreements.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"SNC-Lavalin’s lawyers prepared two legal opinions on the matter that were shared with the PMO, government officials, ministers and ministerial staff. Frank Iacobucci, SNC’s legal counsel and a former Supreme Court justice, shared an opinion with Wilson-Raybould outlining “the legitimacy for her to intervene in criminal matters seized by the prosecution service.”","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"type":"relatedStories","relatedStories":[{"url":"/politics/political-opinion/2019/08/14/ethics-reports-damning-findings-are-a-first-for-a-sitting-prime-minister-but-is-it-enough-to-take-trudeau-down.html","assetId":"f9236d3e-61c2-4cae-91a3-9313caf7ce29","headline":"Opinion | Ethics report’s damning findings are a first for a sitting prime minister but is it enough to take Trudeau down?","abstract":"That it inflicted a direct hit on Trudeau is not in question but it will take a while longer to know whether that makes the Liberal leader a dead man walking, Chantal Hébert writes.","image":{"origImageSize":"1200x852","cropthumb":"0,69,1200,744","lastmodified":1565911011821,"alt":"Prime Minister Justin Trudeau visits the community centre in Niagara-on-the-Lake, Ont. on Aug. 14, 2019. To read the federal ethics commissioner’s accounting of the events surrounding the SNC-Lavalin scandal is to get the impression that the senior levels of the Trudeau government essentially functioned as an arm of the engineering firm, Chantal Hébert writes.","url":"/content/dam/thestar/politics/political-opinion/2019/08/14/ethics-reports-damning-findings-are-a-first-for-a-sitting-prime-minister-but-is-it-enough-to-take-trudeau-down/justin_trudeau.jpg","sizes":{"1:1":{"small":"https://images.thestar.com/LFZ-E6uIaBq0BQNBGZo1mOcpkH8=/0x69:1200x744/100x100/smart/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/politics/political-opinion/2019/08/14/ethics-reports-damning-findings-are-a-first-for-a-sitting-prime-minister-but-is-it-enough-to-take-trudeau-down/justin_trudeau.jpg"},"3:2":{"small":"https://images.thestar.com/DInRBm_zSKi1WLaz9-zlIQgM_dQ=/0x69:1200x744/114x76/smart/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/politics/political-opinion/2019/08/14/ethics-reports-damning-findings-are-a-first-for-a-sitting-prime-minister-but-is-it-enough-to-take-trudeau-down/justin_trudeau.jpg","medium":"https://images.thestar.com/hiQBzUvBTMHL_7-CUJPmuso_Cyo=/0x69:1200x744/330x220/smart/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/politics/political-opinion/2019/08/14/ethics-reports-damning-findings-are-a-first-for-a-sitting-prime-minister-but-is-it-enough-to-take-trudeau-down/justin_trudeau.jpg","large":"https://images.thestar.com/7hQUwN9xckkZeJHs-iQ2Gsr9KWA=/0x69:1200x744/690x460/smart/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/politics/political-opinion/2019/08/14/ethics-reports-damning-findings-are-a-first-for-a-sitting-prime-minister-but-is-it-enough-to-take-trudeau-down/justin_trudeau.jpg"},"21:9":{"large":"https://images.thestar.com/qbFhWSXgKzPb72YKodSPTMYgZZ8=/0x69:1200x744/1080x460/smart/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/politics/political-opinion/2019/08/14/ethics-reports-damning-findings-are-a-first-for-a-sitting-prime-minister-but-is-it-enough-to-take-trudeau-down/justin_trudeau.jpg"}}},"labels":{"section":"Politics","trust":{"name":"Opinion","link":"https://www.thestar.com/trust/glossary.html","description":"Based report","id":"421861756","type":"scribd"},{"text":"The same opinion was shared with Brison. SNC-Lavalin lawyer Robert Prichard wrote in a Nov. 2 email that the company was “considering other ways to make it easier for the minister to engage and reverse the (DPP) decision. In the end, however, it will take a deliberate decision from the centre …”","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"On Nov. 27, Trudeau advisers Bouchard and Elder Marques met with Prichard to discuss Iacobucci’s legal opinion and another, authored by former Supreme Court justice John Major.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"“Mr. Prichard proposed a settlement of the judicial review (into the DPP’s decision not to offer a deal) … indicating the company would settle the action in return for the government’s adoption of a process that would lead to an invitation to negotiate a remediation agreement,” the report reads.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"<ul><li><strong>December 2018</strong></li></ul>","type":"text","isParagraph":false},{"text":"Senior Trudeau political aides, including former principal secretary Gerald Butts and current Chief of Staff Katie Telford, continue to discuss a “solution” for SNC-Lavalin with Wilson-Raybould and her staff. On Dec. 19, former Privy Council Clerk Michael Wernick calls Wilson-Raybould to discuss the case, saying the prime minister remained determined to find a solution for the company and “he’s going to find a way to get it done, one way or another.”","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"<ul><li><strong>December 2018 to Feb. 7, 2019</strong></li></ul>","type":"text","isParagraph":false},{"type":"textBreakPoint","insertAt":"contentEndBreakPoint"},{"text":"Dion reports that “senior staff in the Prime Minister’s Office continue to have discussions with SNC-Lavalin’s legal counsel on next steps and possible solutions until allegations that Ms. Wilson-Raybould had been pressured on the matter were made public on Feb. 7, 2019.” The next day, Dion’s office began its investigation. header"><div class="c-article-labels-container"><div class="primary-label-basic"><a href="/news/canada.html"><div class="label-flag label-pointer label-color-primary">Canada</div></a></div></div><h1 class="c-article-headline__heading c-article-headline__heading--long">Ethics report reveals close co-ordination between Trudeau’s office and SNC-Lavalin</h1></header><div class="article__byline__font c-article-header__byline article__byline-container-author-withphoto" data-lpos="article|author"><div class="article__img-container"><div class="c-author-badge article-byline__author-badge"><img class="c-author-badge__img" src="https://images.thestar.com/8AfGmUZ7p682IZRue10thP6WspY=/100x100/smart/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/columnist_logos/Boutilier_Alex_logo2015.JPG" alt="Alex Boutilier" aria-hidden="true"/></div></div><div class="article__byline"><span class="article__author-by">By </span><span class="article__author"><span class="article__author-name"><span><span><a href="/authors.boutilier_alex.html"><span>Alex Boutilier</span></a></span></span></span><span class="article__author-credit">Ottawa Bureau</span></span><div class="article__time-container"><span class="article__published-date--clickable alcta" data-alparams="{"ltype":"label","ctype":"warning"}"><span><i class="staricon article__published-date--warning-icon staricon-error-reporting"></i></span><span class="article__published-date article__published-date--warning">Wed., Aug. 14, 2019</span></span><span class="published-date-border"></span><span class="article__readtime"><i class="material-icons c-material-icon c-material-icon--article-readtime-clock" role="img" pointer-events="none" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true">timer</i><span>4<!-- --> min. read</span></span></div></div></div></div><div class="c-article-body" data-lpos="article|body"><div class="c-article-body__content"><p class="text-block-container">OTTAWA—SNC-Lavalin executives and lawyers kept in close contact with the Prime Minister’s Office as <a class="text-block__link" oncontextmenu="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" onclick="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" href="https://www.thestar.com/news/justin_trudeau.html">Justin Trudeau</a>’s senior staff worked on finding a “solution” for the Quebec construction giant’s legal woes.</p><p class="text-block-container">Ethics Commissioner Mario Dion’s <a class="text-block__link" oncontextmenu="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" onclick="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" href="http://ciec-ccie.parl.gc.ca/EN/ReportsAndPublications/Pages/TrudeauIIReport.aspx">report</a> on the SNC-Lavalin affair Wednesday revealed new details about the interaction between senior political staff in the Trudeau government and executives at the company.</p><p class="text-block-container">Dion’s investigation, which ruled Trudeau broke the conflict of interest law for the second time, found a senior adviser to the prime minister had been engaged on the question of offering a “deferred prosecution agreement” to SNC-Lavalin since 2016. </p><p class="text-block-container">A deferred prosecution agreement, also called a “remediation agreement” in Dion’s report, would allow SNC-Lavalin to avoid a criminal trial into fraud and bribery allegations — and a 10-year ban on federal contracts, should the company be convicted — in exchange for a monetary penalty and corporate reforms.</p><p class="text-block-container">The company also floated the idea of deferred prosecution agreements with Finance Minister Bill Morneau, a month before his 2018 budget bill amended the Criminal Code to allow them.</p><p class="text-block-container">Below is a select timeline of interactions between senior political staff in the Trudeau government and SNC-Lavalin executives and lawyers.</p><div class="text-block-container"><ul><li><strong>Early 2016</strong></li></ul></div><p class="text-block-container">Trudeau and a senior adviser, Mathieu Bouchard, met with SNC-Lavalin’s CEO and senior representatives. According to Trudeau, the company discussed the consequences of a criminal conviction on the company. Trudeau testified that he instructed Bouchard to look into “remediation agreements” and how other countries handle similar situations, and tasked Bouchard with staying on top of the SNC-Lavalin file. </p><div class="article-related-inline"></div><span style="display:block" id="contentMiddleBreakPoint"></span><div class="text-block-container"><ul><li><strong>Sept. 25 to Nov. 17, 2017</strong></li></ul></div><p class="text-block-container">The federal government holds public consultations on legal tools for dealing with corporate wrongdoing.</p><p class="text-block-container"><strong>Jan. 23, 2018</strong></p><p class="text-block-container">SNC-Lavalin requests a meeting between CEO Neil Bruce and Morneau at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland. Morneau and his policy adviser, Justin To, met with Bruce and the issue of “remediation agreements” came up. According to To, Bruce warned of “negative economic impacts” if the company couldn’t reach a deal.</p><div class="text-block-container"><ul><li><strong>Feb. 2, 2018</strong></li></ul></div><p class="text-block-container">Bruce and other SNC-Lavalin representatives met with To in Ottawa, as a followup to the Davos meeting. From Dion’s report:</p><p class="text-block-container">“The company presented Mr. To with a confidential discussion document outlining reasons in support of a remediation agreement regime and the company’s request for timely implementation of a regime via the federal budget. According to the document, this strategy would increase the likelihood of a settlement of the company’s pending criminal charges, of the company maintaining its head office in Canada for the foreseeable future and of an increase in its workforce.”</p><div class="text-block-container"><ul><li><strong>Feb. 22, 2018</strong></li></ul></div><div class="article-related-inline"></div><p class="text-block-container">The federal government releases the results of a public consultation on deferred prosecution agreements, which found that the majority of respondents supported the idea. Five days later, Morneau’s omnibus budget bill included amendments to the Criminal Code to allow for deferred prosecution agreements.</p><div class="text-block-container"><ul><li><strong>March, 2018</strong></li></ul></div><p class="text-block-container">Trudeau receives a memo from the Privy Council Office, the central agency that supports the prime minister, stating that SNC-Lavalin told federal officials it has a “Plan B” if the government did not bring in deferred prosecution agreements. According to Dion’s report, SNC’s “Plan B” involved splitting up the company and moving parts of SNC-Lavalin Group to another jurisdiction.</p><style class="MuiGrid-root MuiGrid-container MuiGrid-item MuiGrid-justify-xs-flex-end MuiGrid-grid-xs-6"></div></div></div><div class="text-block-container"><ul><li><strong>November 2018</strong></li></ul></div><span style="display:block" id="contentLongBreakPoint"></span><p class="text-block-container">Dion’s report said SNC-Lavalin’s lawyers and representatives began to increase their “communications with government officials and staff in the Prime Minister’s Office with a view to finding solutions to override the Director of Public Prosecutions’ (DPP) decision.”</p><p class="text-block-container">“(Staff) in the Prime Minister’s Office were told that the company’s board of directors was close to escalating measures in respect of their ‘Plan B,’” the report noted.</p><p class="text-block-container">Around the same time, Morneau and then-Treasury Board president Scott Brison met with Kevin Lynch, a former top bureaucrat now working with SNC, at a conference in Beijing, China. According to Morneau and Brison, the conversation was brief but focused on the Director of Public Prosecutions’ decision to not negotiate a deal. SNC told Dion that Lynch also floated the idea of third-party legal experts to provide advice to then-attorney general Jody Wilson-Raybould on remediation agreements.</p><p class="text-block-container">SNC-Lavalin’s lawyers prepared two legal opinions on the matter that were shared with the PMO, government officials, ministers and ministerial staff. Frank Iacobucci, SNC’s legal counsel and a former Supreme Court justice, shared an opinion with Wilson-Raybould outlining “the legitimacy for her to intervene in criminal matters seized by the prosecution service.”</p><div class="article-related-inline"><div class="c-related-articles" data-lpos="article|related-stories"><h2 class="article-list-heading"><div class="article-list-heading-text article-list-heading-text--small">RELATED STORIES</div></h2><div class="c-related-articles-inline__content"><a href="/politics/political-opinion/2019/08/14/ethics-reports-damning-findings-are-a-first-for-a-sitting-prime-minister-but-is-it-enough-to-take-trudeau-down.html" class="c-mediacard c-related-articles__article c-mediacard--row c-mediacard--small-only-row c-mediacard--medium-only-row c-mediacard--large-only-row" data-test-id="mediacard"><div class="c-mediacard__content"><div class="c-mediacard-labels c-mediacard__labels"><span class="c-mediacard-labels__label c-mediacard-labels__label--section" data-test-id="label-section">Politics</span><span class="c-mediacard-labels__label c-mediacard-labels__label--trust" data-test-id="label-trust"><span class="label-trust-text">Opinion</span></span></div><h3 class="c-mediacard__heading mediacard-headline__long"><span data-test-id="mediacard-headline">Opinion | Ethics report’s damning findings are a first for a sitting prime minister but is it enough to take Trudeau down?</span></h3><div class="c-mediacard-footer"><div class="c-mediacard-footer__items-left"><div class="article__published-date"><span><i class="staricon article__published-date--warning-icon staricon-error-reporting"></i></span><span class="article__published-date article__published-date--warning">Aug. 14, 2019</span></div></div></div></div></a></div></div></div><div class="scribd"><h4>Read the full report</h4><div class="scribd-document show-for-medium-up" id="embedded_doc_421861756"></div><a class="show-for-small-only" href="https://www.scribd.com/fullscreen/421861756?access_key=key-14x2zy69z8ecwa0wzhbu" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">View document on Scribd</a></div><p class="text-block-container">The same opinion was shared with Brison. SNC-Lavalin lawyer Robert Prichard wrote in a Nov. 2 email that the company was “considering other ways to make it easier for the minister to engage and reverse the (DPP) decision. In the end, however, it will take a deliberate decision from the centre …”</p><p class="text-block-container">On Nov. 27, Trudeau advisers Bouchard and Elder Marques met with Prichard to discuss Iacobucci’s legal opinion and another, authored by former Supreme Court justice John Major.</p><p class="text-block-container">“Mr. Prichard proposed a settlement of the judicial review (into the DPP’s decision not to offer a deal) … indicating the company would settle the action in return for the government’s adoption of a process that would lead to an invitation to negotiate a remediation agreement,” the report reads.</p><div class="text-block-container"><ul><li><strong>December 2018</strong></li></ul></div><p class="text-block-container">Senior Trudeau political aides, including former principal secretary Gerald Butts and current Chief of Staff Katie Telford, continue to discuss a “solution” for SNC-Lavalin with Wilson-Raybould and her staff. On Dec. 19, former Privy Council Clerk Michael Wernick calls Wilson-Raybould to discuss the case, saying the prime minister remained determined to find a solution for the company and “he’s going to find a way to get it done, one way or another.”</p><div class="text-block-container"><ul><li><strong>December 2018 to Feb. 7, 2019</strong></li></ul></div><span style="display:block" id="contentEndBreakPoint"></span><p class="text-block-container">Dion reports that “senior staff in the Prime Minister’s Office continue to have discussions with SNC-Lavalin’s legal counsel on next steps and possible solutions until allegations that Ms. Wilson-Raybould had been pressured on the matter were made public on Feb. 7, 2019.” The next day, Dion’s office began its investigation. </p><div class="author-endnote-container border-bottom" data-lpos="article|author|bottom"><a class="author-endnote-container__author-img-link" href="/authors.boutilier_alex.html"><div class="c-author-badge author-endnote-container__author-img"><img class="c-author-badge__img" src="https://images.thestar.com/8AfGmUZ7p682IZRue10thP6WspY=/100x100/smart/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/columnist_logos/Boutilier_Alex_logo2015.JPG" alt="Alex Boutilier" aria-hidden="true"/></div></a><div><a class="author-endnote-container__author-link" href="/authors.boutilier_alex.html">Alex Boutilier</a> is an Ottawa-based reporter covering national politics. Follow him on Twitter: <a href="https://twitter.com/alexboutilier">@alexboutilier</a></div></div><div class="related_topics" data-lpos="article|related-topics"><strong>Read more about: </strong><div onContextMenu=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\" onclick=\"theStarLinkClick(event, learned.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"Criticized by those on the right and left of the political spectrum as taxpayer-funded “propaganda,” <a class=\"text-block__link\" onContextMenu=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\" onclick=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\"href=\"https://www.ontarionewsnow.ca/\">ONN</a> produces videos boosting the Progressive Conservative (1565916820173)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/politics/provincial/2019/08/14/ford-government-considering-overhaul-of-controversial-ontario-news-now-promotional-service/ontario_news_now.png","width":538,"height":304,"scalefactor":100},{"url":"https://images.thestar.com/2-DzOO4JNL81WCr3DvFum1_YzhU=/480x271/smart/filters:cb(1565916820173)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/politics/provincial/2019/08/14/ford-government-considering-overhaul-of-controversial-ontario-news-now-promotional-service/ontario_news_now.png","width":480,"height":271,"scalefactor":89},{"url":"https://images.thestar.com/hjcKRGw9WF_1fNMmit0Hp0QsB-A=/400x226/smart/filters:cb(1565916820173)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/politics/provincial/2019/08/14/ford-government-considering-overhaul-of-controversial-ontario-news-now-promotional-service/ontario_news_now.png","width":400,"height":226,"scalefactor":74},{"url":"https://images.thestar.com/uzxk6ujbaXw1dIv79IXztkmD4_E=/320x181/smart/filters:cb(1565916820173)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/politics/provincial/2019/08/14/ford-government-considering-overhaul-of-controversial-ontario-news-now-promotional-service/ontario_news_now.png","width":320,"height":181,"scalefactor":59},{"url":"https://images.thestar.com/F5gJF8ru2Qa5wo61UEqpJAu5eEc=/93x53/smart/filters:cb(1565916820173)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/politics/provincial/2019/08/14/ford-government-considering-overhaul-of-controversial-ontario-news-now-promotional-service/ontario_news_now.png","width":93,"height":53,"scalefactor":17}],"isLandscape":true}},{"text":"But Conservative sources confide that few people are tuning in.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"type":"ad","heading":"ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW","name":"ArticleFirstBigBox","display":"medium-down","pos":"1","interstitial":true,"sizes":[[300,250]]},{"text":"“They’re too long. No one is watching (one minute and 30 second) packs on social (media),” a senior Tory official, speaking confidentially in order to freely discuss internal deliberations, told the Star.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"“We’re reviewing all our communications strategies,” another insider confirmed Wednesday.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"Ford’s government may not pull the plug altogether, but sources say the videos will be radically altered so they can no longer be accused of broadcasting “fake news.”","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"ONN has about 10,500 followers on its Twitter feed — fewer even than many of the Queen’s Park Press Gallery reporters covering Ford for mainstream media outlets and well behind the premier’s 136,000 followers.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"type":"ad","heading":"ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW","name":"ArticleSecondBigBox","display":"medium-down","pos":"2","interstitial":true,"sizes":[[300,250]]},{"text":"While Ford’s ex-chief of staff, Dean French, who resigned in June after a cronyism scandal, was a big believer in the videos, some other Conservatives are not fans.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"type":"articleRelatedInlinePrimary"},{"type":"textBreakPoint","insertAt":"contentMiddleBreakPoint"},{"text":"Several cabinet ministers have privately admitted to resenting being forced to do interviews for the spots, which they deemed a waste of their time, their credibility, and the government’s resources.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"Tory MPPs have also said some constituents question the value of the much-mocked but seldom-viewed videos.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"Ford’s office declined to comment on ONN’s future delivering newslike stories, instead likening its output to “a video press release or a digital householder.”","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"“All recognized parties at the legislature have a caucus budget which is used to communicate with constituents. Ontario News Now is a communications arm of PC caucus services,” the premier’s office said.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"type":"slimcut"},{"text":"ONN is the taxpayer-subsidized version of <a class=\"text-block__link\" onContextMenu=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\" onclick=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\"href=\"http://www.fordnationlive.ca/\">Ford Nation Live</a>, which the Tories used during last year’s victorious election campaign.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"Lyndsey Vanstone, a former broadcast journalist who worked on Ford’s successful 2018 PC leadership bid, does the news-style “stand-ups” for the items.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"Vanstone did the Ford Nation Live clips during the election before the launch of ONN once the Tories took office on June 29, 2018. She and her camera crew often travel with the premier — including to New York City last April.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"type":"articleRelatedInlineSecondary"},{"text":"Ford defended the expense of that junket in an interview with <a class=\"text-block__link\" onContextMenu=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\" onclick=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\"href=\"https://toronto.ctvnews.ca/ford-makes-no-apologies-for-taking-ontario-news-now-on-n-y-trip-1.4404123\">CTV News </a>upon his return.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"“I make no apologies for getting the message out,” the premier told CTV’s Queen’s Park bureau chief Colin D’Mello.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"Opposition parties have charged the videos are partisan advertising at public expense.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"type":"cta","buttonText":"Sign Up Now","buttonLink":"/emails.html?nsrc=article-inline-thisweekinpolitics","description":"Make sense of what's happening across the country and around the world with the Star's This Week in Politics email newsletter.","title":"Get more politics insight in your inbox"},{"text":"Last month, NDP MPP Marit Stiles (Davenport) blasted <a class=\"text-block__link\" onContextMenu=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\" onclick=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\"href=\"https://www.thestar.com/politics/provincial/2019/07/29/winery-hits-sour-note-with-contribution-to-progressive-conservatives.html\">Ford</a> for an ONN <a class=\"text-block__link\" onContextMenu=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\" onclick=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\"href=\"https://twitter.com/fordnation/status/1155571116926230530\">spot</a> where he urged Ontarians to buy wines from Pelee Island Winery.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"“Doug Ford hasn’t learned anything from his patronage appointment scandal,” Stiles said two weeks ago, noting the winery’s president had donated money to the PC party.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"type":"textBreakPoint","insertAt":"contentLongBreakPoint"},{"text":"“Once again, instead of acting like a premier for every Ontarian, Doug Ford is more interested in rewarding PC party supporters. The fact that he’s using his taxpayer-funded fake news channel to do it is an insult to Ontarians,” she said.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"Earlier this year, a <a class=\"text-block__link\" onContextMenu=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\" onclick=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\"href=\"https://www.thestar.com/opinion/editorials/2019/05/31/year-one-of-living-chaotically-in-doug-fords-ontario.html\">Star</a> editorial questioned Ford for establishing “his own propaganda machine, Ontario News Now, a taxpayer-funded vanity project to gush breathlessly about (government) initiatives for the so-called ordinary folks.”","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"type":"relatedStories","relatedStories":[]},{"text":"The <a class=\"text-block__link\" onContextMenu=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\" onclick=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\"href=\"https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-a-propaganda-machine-how-ford-government-skirts-media-with-ontario/\">Globe and Mail </a>reported top ONN staffers are making six-figure salaries for their work.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"Because its costs are covered by the Tory caucus service’s bureau’s annual budget of almost $7 million, it is unclear precisely how much ONN costs taxpayers.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"type":"ad","heading":"ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW","name":"ArticleThirdBigBox","display":"medium-down","pos":"3","interstitial":true,"sizes":[[300,250]]},{"text":"In a <a class=\"text-block__link\" onContextMenu=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\" onclick=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\"href=\"https://nationalpost.com/opinion/ford-shouldnt-waste-taxpayer-money-on-party-propaganda-heres-how-to-stop-it\">National Post </a>op-ed last fall, the Canadian Taxpayers Federation said “there is no doubt … Ontario News Now is a vehicle for partisan publicity.”","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"“It should not be funded by taxpayers. It is a waste of public money and needs to be cut,” wrote the CTF’s Ontario director Christine Van Geyn.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"“Do the government MPPs in Ontario want to face the onslaught of angry taxpayers to save Ford’s propaganda page?” continued Van Geyn.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"“The Ford government has made a commitment to respect taxpayers’ money by reducing spending and waste. Ending Ontario News Now would achieve both.”","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"type":"textBreakPoint","insertAt":"contentEndBreakPoint"},{"text":"In the <a class=\"text-block__link\" onContextMenu=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\" onclick=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\"href=\"https://torontosun.com/opinion/columnists/lilley-after-a-fast-and-furious-2018-doug-ford-plans-to-keep-his-foot-on-the-gas-in-the-new-year\">Toronto Sun</a>, a columnist advised “the distraction of Ontario News Now, the partisan news service, could be fixed by having the party pay for it.”","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"<a class='author-endnote-container__author-link' href='/authors.benzie_rob.html'>Robert Benzie</a> is the Star’s Queen’s Park bureau chief and a reporter covering Ontario politics. class="primary-label-basic"><a href="/politics/provincial.html"><div class="label-flag label-pointer label-color-primary">Provincial Politics</div></a></div></div><h1 class="c-article-headline__heading c-article-headline__heading--long">Ford government considering overhaul of controversial Ontario News Now promotional service</h1></header><div class="article__byline__font c-article-header__byline article__byline-container-author-withphoto" data-lpos="article|author"><div class="article__img-container"><div class="c-author-badge article-byline__author-badge"><img class="c-author-badge__img" src="https://images.thestar.com/u8Q5Fe4H8AsMeTY2jzqQI6blStQ=/100x100/smart/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/columnist_logos/Benzie_Robert_logo2015.JPG" alt="Robert Benzie" aria-hidden="true"/></div></div><div class="article__byline"><span class="article__author-by">By </span><span class="article__author"><span class="article__author-name"><span><span><a href="/authors.benzie_rob.html"><span>Robert Benzie</span></a></span></span></span><span class="article__author-credit">Queen's Park Bureau Chief</span></span><div class="article__time-container"><span class="article__published-date--clickable alcta" data-alparams="{"ltype":"label","ctype":"warning"}"><span><i class="staricon article__published-date--warning-icon staricon-error-reporting"></i></span><span class="article__published-date article__published-date--warning">Wed., Aug. 14, 2019</span></span><span class="published-date-border"></span><span class="article__readtime"><i class="material-icons c-material-icon c-material-icon--article-readtime-clock" role="img" pointer-events="none" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true">timer</i><span>3<!-- --> min. read</span></span></div></div></div></div><div class="c-article-body" data-lpos="article|body"><div class="c-article-body__content"><p class="text-block-container">Premier Doug Ford’s office is considering a dramatic overhaul of its controversial <a class="text-block__link" oncontextmenu="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" onclick="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" href="https://www.ontarionewsnow.ca/premier_ford_visits_businesses_in_bay_of_quinte_with_minister_todd_smith">Ontario News Now </a>promotional video service, the Star has learned.</p><p class="text-block-container">Criticized by those on the right and left of the political spectrum as taxpayer-funded “propaganda,” <a class="text-block__link" oncontextmenu="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" onclick="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" href="https://www.ontarionewsnow.ca/">ONN</a> produces videos boosting the Progressive Conservative government that are designed to look like legitimate TV news packages.</p><p class="text-block-container">But Conservative sources confide that few people are tuning in.</p><p class="text-block-container">“They’re too long. No one is watching (one minute and 30 second) packs on social (media),” a senior Tory official, speaking confidentially in order to freely discuss internal deliberations, told the Star.</p><p class="text-block-container">“We’re reviewing all our communications strategies,” another insider confirmed Wednesday.</p><p class="text-block-container">Ford’s government may not pull the plug altogether, but sources say the videos will be radically altered so they can no longer be accused of broadcasting “fake news.”</p><p class="text-block-container">ONN has about 10,500 followers on its Twitter feed — fewer even than many of the Queen’s Park Press Gallery reporters covering Ford for mainstream media outlets and well behind the premier’s 136,000 followers.</p><p class="text-block-container">While Ford’s ex-chief of staff, Dean French, who resigned in June after a cronyism scandal, was a big believer in the videos, some other Conservatives are not fans.</p><div class="article-related-inline"></div><span style="display:block" id="contentMiddleBreakPoint"></span><p class="text-block-container">Several cabinet ministers have privately admitted to resenting being forced to do interviews for the spots, which they deemed a waste of their time, their credibility, and the government’s resources.</p><p class="text-block-container">Tory MPPs have also said some constituents question the value of the much-mocked but seldom-viewed videos.</p><p class="text-block-container">Ford’s office declined to comment on ONN’s future delivering newslike stories, instead likening its output to “a video press release or a digital householder.”</p><p class="text-block-container">“All recognized parties at the legislature have a caucus budget which is used to communicate with constituents. Ontario News Now is a communications arm of PC caucus services,” the premier’s office said.</p><p class="text-block-container">ONN is the taxpayer-subsidized version of <a class="text-block__link" oncontextmenu="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" onclick="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" href="http://www.fordnationlive.ca/">Ford Nation Live</a>, which the Tories used during last year’s victorious election campaign.</p><p class="text-block-container">Lyndsey Vanstone, a former broadcast journalist who worked on Ford’s successful 2018 PC leadership bid, does the news-style “stand-ups” for the items.</p><p class="text-block-container">Vanstone did the Ford Nation Live clips during the election before the launch of ONN once the Tories took office on June 29, 2018. She and her camera crew often travel with the premier — including to New York City last April.</p><div class="article-related-inline"></div><p class="text-block-container">Ford defended the expense of that junket in an interview with <a class="text-block__link" oncontextmenu="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" onclick="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" href="https://toronto.ctvnews.ca/ford-makes-no-apologies-for-taking-ontario-news-now-on-n-y-trip-1.4404123">CTV News </a>upon his return.</p><p class="text-block-container">“I make no apologies for getting the message out,” the premier told CTV’s Queen’s Park bureau chief Colin D’Mello.</p><p class="text-block-container">Opposition parties have charged the videos are partisan advertising at public expense.</p><style data-emotion-css="12fm3bw">.css-12fm3bw{border-radius:5px;box-shadow:0 2px 8px 0 rgba(0,0,0,0.08);background-color:#fff;padding:14px 24px 16px MuiButton-disableElevation" tabindex="0" type="button" href="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" data-alparams="{"ltype":"other","ctype":"other", "campaign":  "null"}"><span class="MuiButton-label"><span class="c-loading-skeleton c-loading-skeleton--animated" style="width:100%;height:1em;animation-duration:1.2s">Loading...</span></span></button></div><div class="MuiGrid-root MuiGrid-container MuiGrid-item MuiGrid-justify-xs-flex-end MuiGrid-grid-xs-6"></div></div></div><p class="text-block-container">Last month, NDP MPP Marit Stiles (Davenport) blasted <a class="text-block__link" oncontextmenu="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" onclick="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" href="https://www.thestar.com/politics/provincial/2019/07/29/winery-hits-sour-note-with-contribution-to-progressive-conservatives.html">Ford</a> for an ONN <a class="text-block__link" oncontextmenu="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" onclick="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" href="https://twitter.com/fordnation/status/1155571116926230530">spot</a> where he urged Ontarians to buy wines from Pelee Island Winery.</p><p class="text-block-container">“Doug Ford hasn’t learned anything from his patronage appointment scandal,” Stiles said two weeks ago, noting the winery’s president had donated money to the PC party.</p><span style="display:block" id="contentLongBreakPoint"></span><p class="text-block-container">“Once again, instead of acting like a premier for every Ontarian, Doug Ford is more interested in rewarding PC party supporters. The fact that he’s using his taxpayer-funded fake news channel to do it is an insult to Ontarians,” she said.</p><p class="text-block-container">Earlier this year, a <a class="text-block__link" oncontextmenu="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" onclick="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" href="https://www.thestar.com/opinion/editorials/2019/05/31/year-one-of-living-chaotically-in-doug-fords-ontario.html">Star</a> editorial questioned Ford for establishing “his own propaganda machine, Ontario News Now, a taxpayer-funded vanity project to gush breathlessly about (government) initiatives for the so-called ordinary folks.”</p><div class="article-related-inline"></div><p class="text-block-container">The <a class="text-block__link" oncontextmenu="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" onclick="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" href="https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-a-propaganda-machine-how-ford-government-skirts-media-with-ontario/">Globe and Mail </a>reported top ONN staffers are making six-figure salaries for their work.</p><p class="text-block-container">Because its costs are covered by the Tory caucus service’s bureau’s annual budget of almost $7 million, it is unclear precisely how much ONN costs taxpayers.</p><p class="text-block-container">In a <a class="text-block__link" oncontextmenu="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" onclick="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" href="https://nationalpost.com/opinion/ford-shouldnt-waste-taxpayer-money-on-party-propaganda-heres-how-to-stop-it">National Post </a>op-ed last fall, the Canadian Taxpayers Federation said “there is no doubt … Ontario News Now is a vehicle for partisan publicity.”</p><p class="text-block-container">“It should not be funded by taxpayers. It is a waste of public money and needs to be cut,” wrote the CTF’s Ontario director Christine Van Geyn.</p><p class="text-block-container">“Do the government MPPs in Ontario want to face the onslaught of angry taxpayers to save Ford’s propaganda page?” continued Van Geyn.</p><p class="text-block-container">“The Ford government has made a commitment to respect taxpayers’ money by reducing spending and waste. Ending Ontario News Now would achieve both.”</p><span style="display:block" id="contentEndBreakPoint"></span><p class="text-block-container">In the <a class="text-block__link" oncontextmenu="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" onclick="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" href="https://torontosun.com/opinion/columnists/lilley-after-a-fast-and-furious-2018-doug-ford-plans-to-keep-his-foot-on-the-gas-in-the-new-year">Toronto Sun</a>, a columnist advised “the distraction of Ontario News Now, the partisan news service, could be fixed by having the party pay for it.”</p><div class="author-endnote-container border-bottom" data-lpos="article|author|bottom"><a class="author-endnote-container__author-img-link" href="/authors.benzie_rob.html"><div class="c-author-badge author-endnote-container__author-img"><img class="c-author-badge__img" src="https://images.thestar.com/u8Q5Fe4H8AsMeTY2jzqQI6blStQ=/100x100/smart/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/columnist_logos/Benzie_Robert_logo2015.JPG" alt="Robert Benzie" aria-hidden="true"/></div></a><div><a class="author-endnote-container__author-link" href="/authors.benzie_rob.html">Robert Benzie</a> is the Star’s Queen’s Park bureau chief and a reporter covering Ontario politics. Follow him on Twitter: <a href="https://twitter.com/robertbenzie">@robertbenzie</a></div></div><div class="related_topics" data-lpos="article|related-topics"><strong>Read more about: </strong><div .com/content/dam/thestar/vancouver/2019/08/14/former-british-columbia-firefighter-teams-up-with-web-developer-to-create-a-wildfire-app/british_columbia_wildfire.jpg","width":605,"height":434,"scalefactor":50},{"url":"https://images.thestar.com/Nd4ebBGYNCPxMM9Ot5GbyvODPkQ=/480x344/smart/filters:cb(1565823157429)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/vancouver/2019/08/14/former-british-columbia-firefighter-teams-up-with-web-developer-to-create-a-wildfire-app/british_columbia_wildfire.jpg","width":480,"height":344,"scalefactor":40},{"url":"https://images.thestar.com/IqLtIZpTIZycpBrrW0HApgusT44=/400x287/smart/filters:cb(1565823157429)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/vancouver/2019/08/14/former-british-columbia-firefighter-teams-up-with-web-developer-to-create-a-wildfire-app/british_columbia_wildfire.jpg","width":400,"height":287,"scalefactor":33},{"url":"https://images.thestar.com/kUN89FxFSHFUKrqERtVIlaFoImU=/320x230/smart/filters:cb(1565823157429)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/vancouver/2019/08/14/former-british-columbia-firefighter-teams-up-with-web-developer-to-create-a-wildfire-app/british_columbia_wildfire.jpg","width":320,"height":230,"scalefactor":27},{"url":"https://images.thestar.com/bm_C2k5GSbXEiGgllAEf5Nzrj7U=/93x67/smart/filters:cb(1565823157429)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/vancouver/2019/08/14/former-british-columbia-firefighter-teams-up-with-web-developer-to-create-a-wildfire-app/british_columbia_wildfire.jpg","width":93,"height":67,"scalefactor":8}],"isLandscape":true}},{"text":"“We’re just two guys who wanted the B.C. wildfire data accessible quickly on our phones,” says the description of the BC Wildfire app.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"type":"ad","heading":"ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW","name":"ArticleFirstBigBox","display":"medium-down","pos":"1","interstitial":true,"sizes":[[300,250]]},{"text":"The app offers several different maps of wildfires in B.C., Alberta and the western U.S., an evacuation alert map, and a mashup of wildfires across western North America. Each fire is clickable, offering details including the size and estimated cause of the fire.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"“People are used to opening an application and having the information optimized,” said Kilback, adding that all the same information is found on government webpages with extra steps, but this is more accessible on a cellphone when people are camping or out in the woods.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"The number of users for the app varies throughout the year but it peaks during the summer months, said Dyer","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"In 2018, one of the worst years for wildfires in B.C., Dyer said there were more than 40,000 installations.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"type":"ad","heading":"ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW","name":"ArticleSecondBigBox","display":"medium-down","pos":"2","interstitial":true,"sizes":[[300,250]]},{"text":"More than 27,000 users have installed the app so far this year, he said.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"type":"articleRelatedInlinePrimary"},{"type":"textBreakPoint","insertAt":"contentMiddleBreakPoint"},{"text":"For Anthony Ettlinger, the app means he can keep track of where his wife, Leslie Ettlinger, is working. She’s an on-call firefighter at a local fire hall and has been deployed on structure protection several times.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"Ettlinger, who lives outside Vernon, said the provincial wildfire service does a great job of posting information online for people using computers, but he’s had trouble loading the same information on his iPhone.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"“(The app) gives me immediate access to the conditions near where I am.”","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"The Ettlingers moved to Canada from the U.K. in 2015 and quickly realized how prevalent and destructive wildfires can be in B.C.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"type":"slimcut"},{"text":"“There was an actual wildfire that started not far from the house and we sort of watched in amazement as the bombers and helicopters and everybody went in,” said Ettlinger, who recently donated to the BC Wildfire app to help keep it running.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"type":"articleRelatedInlineSecondary"},{"text":"Dyer said he’s grateful it’s been a slow fire season since he and Kilback have been paying hundreds of dollars each month to keep the app running at its peak.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"Last year, Google changed its pricing structure to provide a US$200 monthly credit equivalent to 28,000 free dynamic map loads.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"In June, there were more than 60,000 BC Wildifre map loads, which cost them $336 after Google’s monthly credit was applied.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"Kilback estimates the small team who set out to create the app has paid around $14,000 out of pocket to get the app built and to keep it running. Dyer continues to work on the app for free.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"“We kept getting these emails about how much people loved it,” Kilback said. “We just wanted to keep at it. We didn’t want to give up on the idea.”","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"type":"relatedStories","relatedStories":[{"url":"/vancouver/2018/07/21/what-its-like-on-the-front-lines-of-bcs-wildfire-fight.html","assetId":"468886f8-fa7e-4edb-8ccb-5b190e6839cc","headline":"What article__byline-container-author-withphoto" data-lpos="article|author"><div class="article__img-container"><div class="c-author-badge article-byline__author-badge c-author-badge--no-img"><span class="c-author-badge__initials">BO</span></div></div><div class="article__byline"><span class="article__author-by">By </span><span class="article__author"><span class="article__author-name article__author-name--nolink">Brenna Owen</span><span class="article__author-credit">The Canadian Press</span></span><div class="article__time-container"><span class="article__published-date--clickable alcta" data-alparams="{"ltype":"label","ctype":"warning"}"><span><i class="staricon article__published-date--warning-icon staricon-error-reporting"></i></span><span class="article__published-date article__published-date--warning">Wed., Aug. 14, 2019</span></span><span class="published-date-border"></span><span class="article__readtime"><i class="material-icons c-material-icon c-material-icon--article-readtime-clock" role="img" pointer-events="none" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true">timer</i><span>3<!-- --> min. read</span></span></div></div></div></div><div class="c-article-body" data-lpos="article|body"><div class="c-article-body__content"><p class="text-block-container">VANCOUVER— Former firefighter Aaron Kilback says his friends in B.C.’s Okanagan Valley used to ask him for updates on campfire bans and active wildfires, and he figured it would be easier if the information was all in one place.</p><p class="text-block-container">So, the Penticton, B.C., man and app developer KC Dyer teamed up about four years ago to build a mobile app that compiles active fires and fire danger ratings, evacuation alerts, and air quality reports from the provincial fire service, Environment Canada and NASA.</p><p class="text-block-container">“We’re just two guys who wanted the B.C. wildfire data accessible quickly on our phones,” says the description of the BC Wildfire app.</p><p class="text-block-container">The app offers several different maps of wildfires in B.C., Alberta and the western U.S., an evacuation alert map, and a mashup of wildfires across western North America. Each fire is clickable, offering details including the size and estimated cause of the fire.</p><p class="text-block-container">“People are used to opening an application and having the information optimized,” said Kilback, adding that all the same information is found on government webpages with extra steps, but this is more accessible on a cellphone when people are camping or out in the woods.</p><p class="text-block-container">The number of users for the app varies throughout the year but it peaks during the summer months, said Dyer</p><p class="text-block-container">In 2018, one of the worst years for wildfires in B.C., Dyer said there were more than 40,000 installations.</p><p class="text-block-container">More than 27,000 users have installed the app so far this year, he said.</p><div class="article-related-inline"></div><span style="display:block" id="contentMiddleBreakPoint"></span><p class="text-block-container">For Anthony Ettlinger, the app means he can keep track of where his wife, Leslie Ettlinger, is working. She’s an on-call firefighter at a local fire hall and has been deployed on structure protection several times.</p><p class="text-block-container">Ettlinger, who lives outside Vernon, said the provincial wildfire service does a great job of posting information online for people using computers, but he’s had trouble loading the same information on his iPhone.</p><p class="text-block-container">“(The app) gives me immediate access to the conditions near where I am.”</p><p class="text-block-container">The Ettlingers moved to Canada from the U.K. in 2015 and quickly realized how prevalent and destructive wildfires can be in B.C.</p><p class="text-block-container">“There was an actual wildfire that started not far from the house and we sort of watched in amazement as the bombers and helicopters and everybody went in,” said Ettlinger, who recently donated to the BC Wildfire app to help keep it running.</p><div class="article-related-inline"></div><p class="text-block-container">Dyer said he’s grateful it’s been a slow fire season since he and Kilback have been paying hundreds of dollars each month to keep the app running at its peak.</p><p class="text-block-container">Last year, Google changed its pricing structure to provide a US$200 monthly credit equivalent to 28,000 free dynamic map loads.</p><p class="text-block-container">In June, there were more than 60,000 BC Wildifre map loads, which cost them $336 after Google’s monthly credit was applied.</p><p class="text-block-container">Kilback estimates the small team who set out to create the app has paid around $14,000 out of pocket to get the app built and to keep it running. Dyer continues to work on the app for free.</p><p class="text-block-container">“We kept getting these emails about how much people loved it,” Kilback said. “We just wanted to keep at it. We didn’t want to give up on the idea.”</p><div class="article-related-inline"><div class="c-related-articles" data-lpos="article|related-stories"><h2 class="article-list-heading"><div class="article-list-heading-text article-list-heading-text--small">RELATED STORIES</div></h2><div class="c-related-articles-inline__content"><a href="/vancouver/2018/07/21/what-its-like-on-the-front-lines-of-bcs-wildfire-fight.html" class="c-mediacard c-related-articles__article c-mediacard--row c-mediacard--small-only-row c-mediacard--medium-only-row c-mediacard--large-only-row" data-test-id="mediacard"><div class="c-mediacard__content"><div class="c-mediacard-labels c-mediacard__labels"><span class="c-mediacard-labels__label c-mediacard-labels__label--section" data-test-id="label-section">Vancouver</span></div><h3 class="c-mediacard__heading mediacard-headline__short"><span data-test-id="mediacard-headline">What it’s like on the front lines of B.C.’s wildfire fight</span></h3><div class="c-mediacard-footer"><div class="c-mediacard-footer__items-left"><div class="article__published-date"><span><i class="staricon article__published-date--warning-icon staricon-error-reporting"></i></span><span class="article__published-date article__published-date--warning">Jul. 21, 2018</span></div></div></div></div></a><a href="http://projects.thestar.com/climate-change-canada/alberta/" class="c-mediacard c-related-articles__article c-mediacard--row" data-test-id="externallink-mediacard" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer nofollow"><div class="c-mediacard__content"><h3 class="c-mediacard__heading mediacard-headline__short"><span data-test-id="mediacard-headline">Undeniable | Alberta won't stop burning. Here's why</span></h3></div></a><a href="/news/canada/2019/05/13/what-you-need-to-know-about-bcs-2019-wildfire-season-so-far.html" class="c-mediacard c-related-articles__article c-mediacard--row c-mediacard--small-only-row c-mediacard--medium-only-row c-mediacard--large-only-row" data-test-id="mediacard"><div class="c-mediacard__content"><div class="c-mediacard-labels c-mediacard__labels"><span class="c-mediacard-labels__label c-mediacard-labels__label--section" data-test-id="label-section">Canada</span></div><h3 class="c-mediacard__heading mediacard-headline__long"><span data-test-id="mediacard-headline">What you need to know about B.C.'s 2019 wildfire season so far</span></h3><div class="c-mediacard-footer"><div class="c-mediacard-footer__items-left"><div class="article__published-date"><span><i class="staricon article__published-date--warning-icon staricon-error-reporting"></i></span><span class="article__published-date article__published-date--warning">Aug. 09, 2019</span></div></div></div></div></a></div></div></div><p class="text-block-container">With more money, Kilback said they would like to add more features, like better options for uploading photos and reporting new wildfires and real-time communication between app users and B.C. firefighters.</p><p class="text-block-container">“If we had really good information through the app that we could provide BC Wildfire Service that would help them triage and allocate resources to fires, that would be a huge benefit,” said Kilback, who fought wildfires in the Penticton area for four years.</p><style data-emotion-css="12fm3bw">.css-12fm3bw{border-radius:5px;box-shadow:0 2px 8px 0 class="text-block-container">He and Dyer have approached the BC Wildfire Service in 2017, offering to develop an official app if the fire service covered the costs. The province declined, saying it planned to develop its own mobile app, said Kilback.</p><p class="text-block-container">Despite the setback, Kilback said he still has deep respect for the provincial fire service.</p><span style="display:block" id="contentEndBreakPoint"></span><p class="text-block-container">No one from the Ministry of Forests, Lands & Natural Resource Operations, which oversees the BC Wildfire Service, was available for comment.</p><div class="related_topics" data-lpos="article|related-topics"><strong>Read more about: </strong><div class="tags"><span><span><span><a strong leadership.”","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"Hunter was one of only seven Liberal MPPs to survive the June 2018 election that saw Ford’s Progressive Conservatives romp to victory, ending almost 15 years of Liberal rule.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"“I have a bold goal: we need to knock on one million doors in Ontario by 2022,” said the former minister of education and post-secondary education.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"“One million doors that will win us a mandate to reach 90 per cent graduation rate; one million doors that will win us a mandate to re-skill everybody that lost their job; one million doors that will win us a mandate to make our health care system work for everyone in need and support home caregivers,” she said.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"type":"ad","heading":"ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW","name":"ArticleSecondBigBox","display":"medium-down","pos":"2","interstitial":true,"sizes":[[300,250]]},{"text":"“One million doors to return the Liberal Party of Ontario to Finance Minister Rod Phillips, Hunter is a former chief executive officer of Civic Action, the influential non-partisan civic engagement group.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"Pointing to her background as the daughter of Jamaican immigrants, she noted “my parents saw education and hard work as the keys to opportunity — a belief that I hold deeply and dearly.”","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"“They also taught me that ordinary people can do extraordinary things — and this has been my lifetime passion — to help people achieve their potential.”","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"It’s becoming a more crowded field to lead the <a class=\"text-block__link\" onContextMenu=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\" onclick=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\"href=\"https://www.thestar.com/politics/provincial/2019/06/08/ontario-liberals-wont-change-the-way-they-choose-their-next-leader.html\">Liberals</a>, who will choose their next leader March 7.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"type":"slimcut"},{"text":"The front-runner is former minister <a class=\"text-block__link\" onContextMenu=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\" onclick=\"theStarLinkClick(event, Grit staffer who was the party’s 2018 candidate in Oakville-North Burlington.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"It costs $100,000 to enter the contest — a $75,000 registration fee and a $25,000 “conditionally refundable deposit” — and the deadline for entry is 5 p.m. on Nov. 25. Because that’s after the Oct. 21 federal election, it’s possible some defeated Liberal MPs could join the fray.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"With Ford’s <a class=\"text-block__link\" onContextMenu=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\" onclick=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\"href=\"https://www.thestar.com/politics/provincial/2019/05/16/poll-suggests-pc-support-eroding-after-budget-cuts.html\">personal</a> <a class=\"text-block__link\" onContextMenu=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\" onclick=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\"href=\"https://www.thestar.com/politics/provincial/2019/07/14/more-voters-say-fords-policies-will-deter-them-for-voting-for-scheer.html\">polling</a> in a <a class=\"text-block__link\" onContextMenu=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\" onclick=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\"href=\"https://www.thestar.com/politics/provincial/2019/07/30/ford-says-ontarians-want-him-to-keep-going-ignore-the-media.html\">tailspin</a>, there is more interest in who will lead the provincial Liberals than there has been in the months since former premier Kathleen Wynne’s defeat.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"type":"relatedStories","relatedStories":[]},{"text":"The party membership cut-off is 6 p.m. on Dec. 2 and the delegates who will cast ballots on March 7 will be selected at meetings across Ontario on the weekend of Feb. 8-9.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"At Queen’s Park, the Liberals currently have six seats in the 124-member legislature after the <a class=\"text-block__link\" onContextMenu=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\" onclick=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\"href=\"https://www.thestar.com/politics/provincial/2019/07/31/des-rosiers-quits-as-liberal-mpp-leaving-the-party-at-six-members-of-caucus.html\">retirement</a> last month of Ottawa-Vanier MPP Nathalie Des Rosiers. ","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"type":"cta","buttonText":"Sign Up Now","buttonLink":"/emails.html?nsrc=article-inline-thisweekinpolitics","description":"Make sense of what's happening across the country and around the world with the Star's This Week in Politics email newsletter.","title":"Get more politics insight in your inbox"},{"text":"There are 73 Tories, including Speaker Ted Arnott, who does not caucus with the government, 40 New Democrats, three ex-Tories sitting as Independents, and Green Leader Mike Schreiner.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"Official party status in the house was raised to 12 MPPs from eight by the triumphant Tories last year.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"type":"textBreakPoint","insertAt":"contentEndBreakPoint"},{"text":"Because the Liberals sit below the threshold, they receive no additional funds for research and do not get to ask questions every day in the daily question period.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"<a class='author-endnote-container__author-link' href='/authors.benzie_rob.html'>Robert Benzie</a> is the Star's Queen's Park bureau chief and a reporter covering Ontario politics. Politics</div></a></div></div><h1 class="c-article-headline__heading c-article-headline__heading--long">Mitzie Hunter launches bid for Ontario Liberal leadership</h1></header><div class="article__byline__font c-article-header__byline article__byline-container-author-withphoto" data-lpos="article|author"><div class="article__img-container"><div class="c-author-badge article-byline__author-badge"><img class="c-author-badge__img" src="https://images.thestar.com/u8Q5Fe4H8AsMeTY2jzqQI6blStQ=/100x100/smart/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/columnist_logos/Benzie_Robert_logo2015.JPG" alt="Robert Benzie" aria-hidden="true"/></div></div><div class="article__byline"><span class="article__author-by">By </span><span class="article__author"><span class="article__author-name"><span><span><a href="/authors.benzie_rob.html"><span>Robert Benzie</span></a></span></span></span><span class="article__author-credit">Queen's Park Bureau Chief</span></span><div class="article__time-container"><span class="article__published-date--clickable alcta" data-alparams="{"ltype":"label","ctype":"warning"}"><span><i class="staricon article__published-date--warning-icon staricon-error-reporting"></i></span><span class="article__published-date article__published-date--warning">Wed., Aug. 14, 2019</span></span><span class="published-date-border"></span><span class="article__readtime"><i class="material-icons c-material-icon c-material-icon--article-readtime-clock" role="img" pointer-events="none" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true">timer</i><span>3<!-- --> min. read</span></span></div></div></div></div><div class="c-article-body" data-lpos="article|body"><div class="c-article-body__content"><p class="text-block-container">Mitzie Hunter is in it to win it.</p><p class="text-block-container">The Scarborough-Guildwood MPP has joined the burgeoning contest to lead the Ontario Liberals back from the political wilderness in the next election.</p><p class="text-block-container">“I have the background and experience to lead the Ontario Liberal Party and to take on Doug Ford and his Conservatives ... we can win in 2022,” Hunter told supporters Wednesday night in Scarborough.</p><p class="text-block-container">“We need a Liberal leader who is willing to make bold moves and that will require strong leadership.”</p><p class="text-block-container">Hunter was one of only seven Liberal MPPs to survive the June 2018 election that saw Ford’s Progressive Conservatives romp to victory, ending almost 15 years of Liberal rule.</p><p class="text-block-container">“I have a bold goal: we need to knock on one million doors in Ontario by 2022,” said the former minister of education and post-secondary education.</p><p class="text-block-container">“One million doors that will win us a mandate to reach 90 per cent graduation rate; one million doors that will win us a mandate to re-skill everybody that lost their job; one million doors that will win us a mandate to make our health care system work for everyone in need and support home caregivers,” she said.</p><p class="text-block-container">“One million doors to return the Liberal Party of Ontario to government.”</p><div class="article-related-inline"></div><span style="display:block" id="contentMiddleBreakPoint"></span><p class="text-block-container">Like Toronto Mayor John Tory and PC Finance Minister Rod Phillips, Hunter is a former chief executive officer of Civic Action, the influential non-partisan civic engagement group.</p><p class="text-block-container">Pointing to her background as the daughter of Jamaican immigrants, she noted “my parents saw education and hard work as the keys to opportunity — a belief that I hold deeply and dearly.”</p><p class="text-block-container">“They also taught me that ordinary people can do extraordinary things — and this has been my lifetime passion — to help people achieve their potential.”</p><p class="text-block-container">It’s becoming a more crowded field to lead the <a class="text-block__link" oncontextmenu="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" onclick="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" href="https://www.thestar.com/politics/provincial/2019/06/08/ontario-liberals-wont-change-the-way-they-choose-their-next-leader.html">Liberals</a>, who will choose their next leader March 7.</p><p class="text-block-container">The front-runner is former minister <a class="text-block__link" oncontextmenu="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" onclick="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" href="https://www.thestar.com/politics/provincial/2019/04/02/steven-del-duca-to-seek-ontario-liberal-leadership-with-ambitious-plan-to-rebuild-decimated-party.html">Steven Del Duca</a>, but Don Valley East MPP <a class="text-block__link" oncontextmenu="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" onclick="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" href="https://www.thestar.com/politics/provincial/2019/06/16/michael-coteau-enters-race-to-lead-ontario-liberals.html">Michael Coteau</a>, another former minister, is also considered a strong candidate.</p><div class="article-related-inline"></div><p class="text-block-container">A longer shot is <a class="text-block__link" oncontextmenu="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" onclick="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" href="https://www.thestar.com/politics/provincial/2019/05/23/former-liberal-candidate-to-jump-into-partys-leadership-race.html">Alvin Tedjo</a>, a former Grit staffer who was the party’s 2018 candidate in Oakville-North Burlington.</p><p class="text-block-container">It costs $100,000 to enter the contest — a $75,000 registration fee and a $25,000 “conditionally refundable deposit” — and the deadline for entry is 5 p.m. on Nov. 25. Because that’s after the Oct. 21 federal election, it’s possible some defeated Liberal MPs could join the fray.</p><p class="text-block-container">With Ford’s <a class="text-block__link" oncontextmenu="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" onclick="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" href="https://www.thestar.com/politics/provincial/2019/05/16/poll-suggests-pc-support-eroding-after-budget-cuts.html">personal</a> <a class="text-block__link" oncontextmenu="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" onclick="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" href="https://www.thestar.com/politics/provincial/2019/07/14/more-voters-say-fords-policies-will-deter-them-for-voting-for-scheer.html">polling</a> in a <a class="text-block__link" oncontextmenu="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" onclick="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" href="https://www.thestar.com/politics/provincial/2019/07/30/ford-says-ontarians-want-him-to-keep-going-ignore-the-media.html">tailspin</a>, there is more interest in who will lead the provincial Liberals than there has been in the months since former premier Kathleen Wynne’s defeat.</p><div class="article-related-inline"></div><p class="text-block-container">The party membership cut-off is 6 p.m. on Dec. 2 and the delegates who will cast ballots on March 7 will be selected at meetings across Ontario on the weekend of Feb. 8-9.</p><p class="text-block-container">At Queen’s Park, the Liberals currently have six seats in the 124-member legislature after the <a class="text-block__link" oncontextmenu="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" onclick="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" href="https://www.thestar.com/politics/provincial/2019/07/31/des-rosiers-quits-as-liberal-mpp-leaving-the-party-at-six-members-of-caucus.html">retirement</a> last month of Ottawa-Vanier MPP Nathalie Des Rosiers. </p><style data-emotion-css="12fm3bw">.css-12fm3bw{border-radius:5px;box-shadow:0 2px 8px 0 rgba(0,0,0,0.08);background-color:#fff;padding:14px 24px 16px who does not caucus with the government, 40 New Democrats, three ex-Tories sitting as Independents, and Green Leader Mike Schreiner.</p><p class="text-block-container">Official party status in the house was raised to 12 MPPs from eight by the triumphant Tories last year.</p><span style="display:block" id="contentEndBreakPoint"></span><p class="text-block-container">Because the Liberals sit below the threshold, they receive no additional funds for research and do not get to ask questions every day in the daily question period.</p><div class="author-endnote-container border-bottom" Plus, he says he’s providing a service for neighbours, who will patiently wait in line, even in sweltering heat.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"type":"ad","heading":"ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW","name":"ArticleSecondBigBox","display":"medium-down","pos":"2","interstitial":true,"sizes":[[300,250]]},{"text":"Alex has never worked in a restaurant, but has long enjoyed barbecuing for friends and family. He’s the kind of guy who passes platefuls of meat over the fence to salivating neighbours. His career was spent in management at an automotive parts company and then with human resources departments doing recruitment. A back injury in 2011 forced him into early retirement. And in 2016, he suffered a serious stroke, affecting the mobility on his right side, which is why he now walks with a cane.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"type":"textBreakPoint","insertAt":"contentMiddleBreakPoint"},{"type":"articleRelatedInlinePrimary"},{"text":"Last summer, he fired up the grill for a friend, who said his ribs were delicious and urged him to participate in a rib fest. In the months that followed, he studied safe food handling techniques, read up on cooking practices and created excel spread sheets, compiling data on supply costs, suppliers and how profitable a rib fest business could be. And, he learned that really successful pit masters, those who do the rib fest circuit, can earn six-figure salaries. That’s why he recently started a company to work at rib fests, so that he can build up a successful business to pass on to his two grown daughters.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"captionPosition":"overlay","origImageSize":"1200x800","fullWindowGenericImage":false,"lastmodified":1565736369183,"forceoriginal":false,"caption":"Alex uses a spray bottle to baste his ribs.
