69183)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/gta/2019/08/14/this-toronto-homeowner-wants-to-sell-you-his-barbecue-backyard-ribs/_3_bbq.jpg","width":480,"height":320,"scalefactor":40},{"url":"https://images.thestar.com/0-vmGkVigjo5s-_BQrTHsXaqWu4=/400x267/smart/filters:cb(1565736369183)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/gta/2019/08/14/this-toronto-homeowner-wants-to-sell-you-his-barbecue-backyard-ribs/_3_bbq.jpg","width":400,"height":267,"scalefactor":33},{"url":"https://images.thestar.com/mFzr5W9JGqQmEHSM8s9Au8J-2GU=/320x213/smart/filters:cb(1565736369183)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/gta/2019/08/14/this-toronto-homeowner-wants-to-sell-you-his-barbecue-backyard-ribs/_3_bbq.jpg","width":320,"height":213,"scalefactor":27},{"url":"https://images.thestar.com/VJkOGt_of73AzGa1X9zS-daT_DQ=/93x62/smart/filters:cb(1565736369183)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/gta/2019/08/14/this-toronto-homeowner-wants-to-sell-you-his-barbecue-backyard-ribs/_3_bbq.jpg","width":93,"height":62,"scalefactor":8}]},{"text":"This spring he bought a state-of-the art Myron Mixon Gravity Feed smoker — the kind used by professionals — and a crane was needed to lift it over his house. He’s been running his backyard venture since June and over the course of a weekend gets about 20 customers — preorders are recommended, but he also serves folks who walk in off the street.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"The law in Ontario allows people to run a food business out of their home, but they must comply with <a class=\"text-block__link\" onContextMenu=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\" onclick=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\"href=\"https://www.ontario.ca/laws/regulation/R17493\">Food Premises Regulation 493/17, under the Health Protection and Promotion Act</a>. And Toronto public health officials must be allowed to inspect the site to help prevent food-borne illness and ensure compliance with provincial food safety regulations and <a class=\"text-block__link\" onContextMenu=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\" onclick=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\"href=\"https://www.toronto.ca/city-government/planning-development/zoning-by-law-preliminary-zoning-reviews/zoning-by-law-569-2013-2/\">municipal zoning bylaws</a>.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"If someone is “preparing, handling, selling or offering food for sale — or donations — the business is considered a food premises,” explains department spokesperson Sylvanus Thompson, the associate director of Healthy Environments. “Donations to cover costs do not exempt this business from these requirements.”","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"type":"slimcut"},{"text":"When the department learns food is being sold at a private residence it contacts the person responsible to make sure they’re aware of the rules. c-article-headline__heading--long">This Toronto homeowner wants to sell you his barbecue back(yard) ribs</h1></header><div class="article__byline__font c-article-header__byline article__byline-container-author-withphoto" data-lpos="article|author"><div class="article__img-container"><div class="c-author-badge article-byline__author-badge"><img class="c-author-badge__img" src="https://images.thestar.com/VBe8JajoC4SAdlWK8krTWfN7k_U=/100x100/smart/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/columnist_logos/Teotonio_Isabel_logo2015.JPG" alt="Isabel Teotonio" aria-hidden="true"/></div></div><div class="article__byline"><span class="article__author-by">By </span><span class="article__author"><span class="article__author-name"><span><span><a data-path="/news/gta/2019/08/14/this-toronto-homeowner-wants-to-sell-you-his-barbecue-backyard-ribs.html" data-unique_id="0cd1f916-feca-40bd-81e3-1ab2c06e43f3"></span></div></span></div></div></div><div class="c-article-body" data-lpos="article|body"><div class="c-article-body__content"><p class="text-block-container">In the backyard of a west-end home, Alex carefully tends to his smoker, cooking ribs, brisket, pulled pork and chicken. </p><p class="text-block-container">Then he waits for the meat to become succulent — and for customers to arrive.</p><p class="text-block-container">“They love it,” Alex says. “People from the neighbourhood say it’s great ... It’s been all positive. I’ve had nothing negative from anybody, either in terms of what I’m doing or the quality of the food.”</p><p class="text-block-container">The 63-year-old is illegally selling barbecued meat — “We’re taking donations to cover costs” — from his backyard on weekends because he wants to know if he’s got the culinary chops needed to participate at rib fests. </p><p class="text-block-container">“I just wanted to find out how good I am,” says Alex, who’s been gaining attention on social media with foodies posting about the mysterious location. “Word is getting out like crazy.” </p><p class="text-block-container">Flyers are posted on lamp posts around his west-end neighbourhood, promoting the backyard joint — Alex says his prices are cheaper than what you’d pay at a smokehouse — such as $35 for a three-pound rack of back ribs, $15 for a pound of pulled pork, for example. And on weekends a chalkboard sign on the veranda beckons “Smoked Ribs!” and urges passersby to “Come on in the Backyard.”</p><div class="image article-content__image image__has-rightrail pure-image data-alparams="{"ltype":"pageaction","ctype":"expand","label":"caption", "position": "undefined"" aria-label="Show Caption"><i class="staricon show-caption-icon staricon-caption-show"></i></button></div></div><p class="text-block-container">He just recently learned from reporters that what he’s doing is illegal and asked the Star to withhold his last name. Still, he explains that he’s not really running a business — it’s more like a practice run for rib fest. Plus, he says he’s providing a service for neighbours, who will patiently wait in line, even in sweltering heat.</p><p class="text-block-container">Alex has never worked in a restaurant, but has long enjoyed barbecuing for friends and family. He’s the kind of guy who passes platefuls of meat over the fence to salivating neighbours. His career was spent in management at an automotive parts company and then with human resources departments doing recruitment. A back injury in 2011 forced him into early retirement. And in 2016, he suffered a serious stroke, affecting the mobility on his right side, which is why he now walks with a cane.</p><span style="display:block" id="contentMiddleBreakPoint"></span><div class="article-related-inline"></div><p class="text-block-container">Last summer, he fired up the grill for a friend, who said his ribs were delicious and urged him to participate in a rib fest. In the months that followed, he studied safe food handling techniques, read up on cooking practices and created excel spread sheets, compiling data on supply costs, suppliers and how profitable a rib fest business could be. And, he learned that really successful pit masters, those who do the rib fest circuit, can earn six-figure salaries. That’s why he recently started a company to work at rib fests, so that he can build up a successful business to pass on to his two grown daughters.</p><div class="image article-content__image image__has-rightrail pure-image hideRegistration image--flush-sides"><div class="image__body white-background"><img src="https://images.thestar.com/6UBcdHn5rv2lh1SOu-h-Uh3gShc=/850x567/smart/filters:cb(1565736369183)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/gta/2019/08/14/this-toronto-homeowner-wants-to-sell-you-his-barbecue-backyard-ribs/_3_bbq.jpg" srcset="https://images.thestar.com/6UBcdHn5rv2lh1SOu-h-Uh3gShc=/850x567/smart/filters:cb(1565736369183)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/gta/2019/08/14/this-toronto-homeowner-wants-to-sell-you-his-barbecue-backyard-ribs/_3_bbq.jpg 480w,https://images.thestar.com/0-vmGkVigjo5s-_BQrTHsXaqWu4=/400x267/smart/filters:cb(1565736369183)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/gta/2019/08/14/this-toronto-homeowner-wants-to-sell-you-his-barbecue-backyard-ribs/_3_bbq.jpg 400w,https://images.thestar.com/mFzr5W9JGqQmEHSM8s9Au8J-2GU=/320x213/smart/filters:cb(1565736369183)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/gta/2019/08/14/this-toronto-homeowner-wants-to-sell-you-his-barbecue-backyard-ribs/_3_bbq.jpg 320w" alt="Alex uses a spray bottle to baste his ribs."/></div><div class="caption-container"><button type="button" class="caption-button alcta" data-alparams="{"ltype":"pageaction","ctype":"expand","label":"caption", "position": "undefined"" aria-label="Show Caption"><i class="staricon show-caption-icon staricon-caption-show"></i></button></div></div><p class="text-block-container">This spring he bought a state-of-the art Myron Mixon Gravity Feed smoker — the kind used by professionals — and a crane was needed to lift it over his house. He’s been running his backyard venture since June and over the course of a weekend gets about 20 customers — preorders are recommended, but he also serves folks who walk in off the street.</p><p class="text-block-container">The law in Ontario allows people to run a food business out of their home, but they must comply with <a class="text-block__link" oncontextmenu="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" onclick="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" href="https://www.ontario.ca/laws/regulation/R17493">Food Premises Regulation 493/17, under the Health Protection and Promotion Act</a>. And Toronto public health officials must be allowed to inspect the site to help prevent food-borne illness and ensure compliance with provincial food safety regulations and <a class="text-block__link" oncontextmenu="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" onclick="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" href="https://www.toronto.ca/city-government/planning-development/zoning-by-law-preliminary-zoning-reviews/zoning-by-law-569-2013-2/">municipal zoning bylaws</a>.</p><p class="text-block-container">If someone is “preparing, handling, selling or offering food for sale — or donations — the business is considered a food premises,” explains department spokesperson Sylvanus Thompson, the associate director of Healthy Environments. “Donations to cover costs do not exempt this business from these requirements.”</p><p class="text-block-container">When the department learns food is being sold at a private residence it contacts the person responsible to make sure they’re aware of the rules. And, if an inspection is done, results are posted on its <a class="text-block__link" oncontextmenu="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" onclick="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" href="https://www.toronto.ca/health/dinesafe/index.htm">DineSafe</a> website and must be displayed at the site.</p><div class="image article-content__image image__has-rightrail pure-image hideRegistration image--flush-sides"><div class="image__body white-background"><img src="https://images.thestar.com/b9IrGqjF5tajy2x-C4s49cxuZ0Q=/850x567/smart/filters:cb(1565736369399)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/news/gta/2019/08/14/this-toronto-homeowner-wants-to-sell-you-his-barbecue-backyard-ribs/_4_sign.jpg" staricon-caption-show"></i></button></div></div><div class="article-related-inline"></div><p class="text-block-container">Brian Thompson, manager of Healthy Environments, says most people abandon the idea of running a food premises out of their home once they learn about all the regulations. The few who don’t tend to run businesses such as catering or food takeout services.</p><style data-emotion-css="12fm3bw">.css-12fm3bw{border-radius:5px;box-shadow:0 2px 8px 0 isn’t zoned for commercial use or for a takeout eating establishment. </p><div class="article-related-inline"></div><p class="text-block-container">Still, he insists he is following safe food handling techniques and providing quality food.</p><p class="text-block-container">Alex says, when he thinks of his expenses to date, that he’s still in the red from start-up costs for things such as the smoker, stainless steel pans and commercial-grade sanitizers. </p><p class="text-block-container">But, his drive to make it to rib fest has given him a sense of purpose.</p><span style="display:block" id="contentEndBreakPoint"></span><p class="text-block-container">“I’m a different person now. I’ve got bounce in my step.”</p><div class="author-endnote-container border-bottom" data-lpos="article|author|bottom"><a class="author-endnote-container__author-img-link" href="/authors.teotonio_isabel.html"><div class="c-author-badge author-endnote-container__author-img"><img class="c-author-badge__img" src="https://images.thestar.com/VBe8JajoC4SAdlWK8krTWfN7k_U=/100x100/smart/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/columnist_logos/Teotonio_Isabel_logo2015.JPG" alt="Isabel Teotonio" aria-hidden="true"/></div></a><div><a class="author-endnote-container__author-link" href="/authors.teotonio_isabel.html">Isabel Teotonio</a> is a Toronto-based reporter. g","width":650,"height":462,"scalefactor":54},{"url":"https://images.thestar.com/qffT7rV8oh9v9b19K0tHmBv-nLs=/605x430/smart/filters:cb(1565911011821)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/politics/political-opinion/2019/08/14/ethics-reports-damning-findings-are-a-first-for-a-sitting-prime-minister-but-is-it-enough-to-take-trudeau-down/justin_trudeau.jpg","width":605,"height":430,"scalefactor":50},{"url":"https://images.thestar.com/0F2f75DY-SMwBqAQpUcEYhr5uSk=/480x341/smart/filters:cb(1565911011821)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/politics/political-opinion/2019/08/14/ethics-reports-damning-findings-are-a-first-for-a-sitting-prime-minister-but-is-it-enough-to-take-trudeau-down/justin_trudeau.jpg","width":480,"height":341,"scalefactor":40},{"url":"https://images.thestar.com/gKBf01Tf5TVbd1A-GM5roxzL424=/400x284/smart/filters:cb(1565911011821)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/politics/political-opinion/2019/08/14/ethics-reports-damning-findings-are-a-first-for-a-sitting-prime-minister-but-is-it-enough-to-take-trudeau-down/justin_trudeau.jpg","width":400,"height":284,"scalefactor":33},{"url":"https://images.thestar.com/xIgvv1C3XBX01f4D3ej9JpN9wdQ=/320x227/smart/filters:cb(1565911011821)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/politics/political-opinion/2019/08/14/ethics-reports-damning-findings-are-a-first-for-a-sitting-prime-minister-but-is-it-enough-to-take-trudeau-down/justin_trudeau.jpg","width":320,"height":227,"scalefactor":27},{"url":"https://images.thestar.com/Oj4_F7tfZX6_ZlosM8Mz1FB6iw8=/93x66/smart/filters:cb(1565911011821)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/politics/political-opinion/2019/08/14/ethics-reports-damning-findings-are-a-first-for-a-sitting-prime-minister-but-is-it-enough-to-take-trudeau-down/justin_trudeau.jpg","width":93,"height":66,"scalefactor":8}],"isLandscape":true}},{"text":"Yes, Jean Chrétien and Paul Martin were splattered by the sponsorship scandal. And Stephen Harper spent his last year in office embroiled in a senate scandal that involved the second most powerful player in his office.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"type":"ad","heading":"ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW","name":"ArticleFirstBigBox","display":"medium-down","pos":"1","interstitial":true,"sizes":[[300,250]]},{"text":"But neither Chrétien, nor Martin, nor Harper were singled out in the way that <a class=\"text-block__link\" onContextMenu=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\" onclick=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\"href=\"https://www.thestar.com/news/justin_trudeau.html\">Justin Trudeau </a>is in the <a class=\"text-block__link\" onContextMenu=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\" onclick=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\"href=\"http://ciec-ccie.parl.gc.ca/EN/ReportsAndPublications/Pages/TrudeauIIReport.aspx\">report</a> released on Wednesday by ethics watchdog Mario Dion.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"(As an aside, despite their leaders having been absolved of direct responsibility, the Liberals and Conservatives paid a hefty price in the ballot box for the events that unfolded on their parties’ respective watches in power.)","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"Anyone who believed the prime minister could not come out looking worse for his handling of the SNC-Lavalin file than in the <a class=\"text-block__link\" onContextMenu=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\" onclick=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\"href=\"https://www.thestar.com/politics/federal/2019/02/27/what-jody-wilson-raybould-said.html\">testimony of former attorney-general Jody Wilson-Raybould </a>will discover that the picture Dion paints is even more devastating.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"That’s because it documents PMO efforts on behalf of and/or orchestrated in tandem with SNC-Lavalin to secure a remediation agreement to spare the Quebec engineering giant a possible criminal conviction that go beyond those already revealed by Wilson-Raybould.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"type":"ad","heading":"ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW","name":"ArticleSecondBigBox","display":"medium-down","pos":"2","interstitial":true,"sizes":[[300,250]]},{"text":"To read the ethics commissioner’s accounting of the events is to get the impression that the senior levels of the government essentially functioned as an arm of the engineering firm. The line between the two was not so much blurred as virtually invisible.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"The commissioner’s conclusion that the prime minister violated the federal ethics law is unadulterated.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"type":"textBreakPoint","insertAt":"contentMiddleBreakPoint"},{"text":"He finds no extenuating circumstances to absolve Trudeau of having applied improper pressures on the then-attorney-general to overrule her prosecutors in their dealings with SNC-Lavalin.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"Dion rejects the rationale that the prime minister was only acquitting himself of his duty by trying to mitigate the economic fallout of a negative legal outcome for SNC-Lavalin. ","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"He refutes the notion that because Wilson-Raybould ultimately stuck to her course, no line was crossed, noting that it is not the outcome of the arm-twisting that determines whether it took place.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"type":"slimcut"},{"text":"Nor did Dion find merit in the suggestions that the former attorney-general was difficult to work with or that she had given Trudeau cause to doubt she had done due diligence on the file.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"The ethics commissioner did not even give the prime minister much of the benefit of the doubt for possibly having been abetted by aides overzealous in their efforts to achieve what their boss wanted.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"On the contrary Dion writes: “As prime minister, Mr. Trudeau was the only public office holder who, by virtue of his position, could clearly exert influence over Ms. Wilson-Raybould.” He adds: “…the evidence abundantly shows that Mr. Trudeau knowingly sought to influence Ms. Wilson-Raybould both directly and through the actions of his agents.”","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"captionPosition":"overlay","origImageSize":"4349x2970","fullWindowGenericImage":false,"lastmodified":1565821009407,"forceoriginal":false,"caption":"Jody Wilson-Raybould, former Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada, and Jane Philpott, former Minister of Health, are seen leaving the House of Commons in this file photo taken in Ottawa on Thursday, April 13, 2017. ","type":"genericimage","credit":"THE CANADIAN PRESS/Sean Kilpatrick","url":"/content/dam/thestar/uploads/2019/08/14/skp104540068-0.jpg","crop":"0,0,4349,2970","renditions":[{"url":"https://images.thestar.com/Z1R_mrbFC26uDpWHlMhxA19Ac_E=/0x0:4349x2970/4349x2970/smart/filters:cb(1565821009407)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/uploads/2019/08/14/skp104540068-0.jpg","width":4349,"height":2970,"scalefactor":100},{"url":"https://images.thestar.com/IMYlQV1hj4X8NJRpW1o8jUEg7mk=/0x0:4349x2970/1086x742/smart/filters:cb(1565821009407)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/uploads/2019/08/14/skp104540068-0.jpg","width":1086,"height":742,"scalefactor":25},{"url":"https://images.thestar.com/jJ2GhJkmP2Y5pduTbf9FhNXF9tg=/0x0:4349x2970/968x661/smart/filters:cb(1565821009407)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/uploads/2019/08/14/skp104540068-0.jpg","width":968,"height":661,"scalefactor":22},{"url":"https://images.thestar.com/guv4nd2Wm544XpXLMOhrYTD_WPk=/0x0:4349x2970/850x580/smart/filters:cb(1565821009407)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/uploads/2019/08/14/skp104540068-0.jpg","width":850,"height":580,"scalefactor":20},{"url":"https://images.thestar.com/hoz7_n3cA9gtH8FzkVhX6mlWGX8=/0x0:4349x2970/650x444/smart/filters:cb(1565821009407)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/uploads/2019/08/14/skp104540068-0.jpg","width":650,"height":444,"scalefactor":15},{"url":"https://images.thestar.com/vk7uHnMpGQRsPV6P2ddFhkhbJUI=/0x0:4349x2970/605x413/smart/filters:cb(1565821009407)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/uploads/2019/08/14/skp104540068-0.jpg","width":605,"height":413,"scalefactor":14},{"url":"https://images.thestar.com/Wvp208537E4bLNiGzJ1WbJJuNMw=/0x0:4349x2970/480x328/smart/filters:cb(1565821009407)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/uploads/2019/08/14/skp104540068-0.jpg","width":480,"height":328,"scalefactor":11},{"url":"https://images.thestar.com/822MtI16sJngDNXuF1rKooX3TIU=/0x0:4349x2970/400x273/smart/filters:cb(1565821009407)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/uploads/2019/08/14/skp104540068-0.jpg","width":400,"height":273,"scalefactor":9},{"url":"https://images.thestar.com/JW5QSM9_e1tQOyiwJhxAv2SpK3Q=/0x0:4349x2970/320x219/smart/filters:cb(1565821009407)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/uploads/2019/08/14/skp104540068-0.jpg","width":320,"height":219,"scalefactor":7},{"url":"https://images.thestar.com/xbFAo_6ZwgKkmTBcpTSRZGdiMfY=/0x0:4349x2970/93x64/smart/filters:cb(1565821009407)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/uploads/2019/08/14/skp104540068-0.jpg","width":93,"height":64,"scalefactor":2}]},{"text":"Liberal sources say they had no heads-up about the imminent release of the report. Earlier this week, PMO officials still estimated that the findings would be published in early September.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"The fact that the report landed sooner rather than later may be the only saving grace for the government in the latest instalment of the saga that has plagued the Liberals since last winter. ","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"The closer to the vote the harder it would be to contain the damage of a bombshell of this magnitude.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"If the <a class=\"text-block__link\" onContextMenu=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\" onclick=\"theStarLinkClick(event, this)\"href=\"https://www.thestar.com/news/federal-election.html\">election</a> were not so close, Trudeau’s future as Liberal leader and prime minister might become a matter for internal debate within his party’s ranks. In other circumstances Dion’s report would amount to putting a big target on the leader’s back.","type":"text","isParagraph":true},{"text":"But the proximity of the federal campaign, to be launched officially next month, will almost certainly temper the temptation to look for a possible saviour. class="primary-label-basic"><a href="/politics.html"><div class="label-flag label-pointer label-color-primary">Politics</div></a></div><div class="text-label-basic"><div><span class="text-label-text alcta" data-alparams="{"ltype":"label","ctype":"trust", "label": "Opinion"}">Opinion</span></div></div></div><h1 class="c-article-headline__heading c-article-headline__heading--long">Ethics report’s damning findings are a first for a sitting prime minister but is it enough to take Trudeau down?</h1></header><div class="article__byline__font c-article-header__byline article__byline-container-author-withphoto" data-lpos="article|author"><div class="article__img-container"><div class="c-author-badge article-byline__author-badge"><img class="c-author-badge__img" src="https://images.thestar.com/zcriBH5GetcognR9ZhuQd39SFW4=/100x100/smart/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/columnist_logos/Hebert_Chantal_logo2016W.jpg" alt="Chantal Hébert" aria-hidden="true"/></div></div><div class="article__byline"><span class="article__author-by">By </span><span class="article__author"><span class="article__author-name"><span><span><a href="/authors.h_bert_chantal.html"><span>Chantal Hébert</span></a></span></span></span><span class="article__author-credit">Star Columnist</span></span><div class="article__time-container"><span class="article__published-date--clickable alcta" data-alparams="{"ltype":"label","ctype":"warning"}"><span><i class="staricon article__published-date--warning-icon staricon-error-reporting"></i></span><span class="article__published-date article__published-date--warning">Wed., Aug. 14, 2019</span></span><span class="published-date-border"></span><span class="article__readtime"><i class="material-icons c-material-icon c-material-icon--article-readtime-clock" role="img" pointer-events="none" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true">timer</i><span>4<!-- --> min. read</span></span></div></div></div></div><div class="c-article-body" data-lpos="article|body"><div class="c-article-body__content"><p class="text-block-container">MONTREAL—Where to start?</p><p class="text-block-container">The ethics commissioner report on the <a class="text-block__link" oncontextmenu="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" onclick="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" href="https://www.thestar.com/politics/pmo-scandal.html">SNC-Lavalin affair</a> contains the most damning findings ever rendered by an officer of Parliament against a sitting prime minister.</p><p class="text-block-container">Yes, Jean Chrétien and Paul Martin were splattered by the sponsorship scandal. And Stephen Harper spent his last year in office embroiled in a senate scandal that involved the second most powerful player in his office.</p><p class="text-block-container">But neither Chrétien, nor Martin, nor Harper were singled out in the way that <a class="text-block__link" oncontextmenu="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" onclick="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" href="https://www.thestar.com/news/justin_trudeau.html">Justin Trudeau </a>is in the <a class="text-block__link" oncontextmenu="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" onclick="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" href="http://ciec-ccie.parl.gc.ca/EN/ReportsAndPublications/Pages/TrudeauIIReport.aspx">report</a> released on Wednesday by ethics watchdog Mario Dion.</p><p class="text-block-container">(As an aside, despite their leaders having been absolved of direct responsibility, the Liberals and Conservatives paid a hefty price in the ballot box for the events that unfolded on their parties’ respective watches in power.)</p><p class="text-block-container">Anyone who believed the prime minister could not come out looking worse for his handling of the SNC-Lavalin file than in the <a class="text-block__link" oncontextmenu="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" onclick="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" href="https://www.thestar.com/politics/federal/2019/02/27/what-jody-wilson-raybould-said.html">testimony of former attorney-general Jody Wilson-Raybould </a>will discover that the picture Dion paints is even more devastating.</p><p class="text-block-container">That’s because it documents PMO efforts on behalf of and/or orchestrated in tandem with SNC-Lavalin to secure a remediation agreement to spare the Quebec engineering giant a possible criminal conviction that go beyond those already revealed by Wilson-Raybould.</p><p class="text-block-container">To read the ethics commissioner’s accounting of the events is to get the impression that the senior levels of the government essentially functioned as an arm of the engineering firm. The line between the two was not so much blurred as virtually invisible.</p><p class="text-block-container">The commissioner’s conclusion that the prime minister violated the federal ethics law is unadulterated.</p><span style="display:block" id="contentMiddleBreakPoint"></span><p class="text-block-container">He finds no extenuating circumstances to absolve Trudeau of having applied improper pressures on the then-attorney-general to overrule her prosecutors in their dealings with SNC-Lavalin.</p><p class="text-block-container">Dion rejects the rationale that the prime minister was only acquitting himself of his duty by trying to mitigate the economic fallout of a negative legal outcome for SNC-Lavalin. </p><p class="text-block-container">He refutes the notion that because Wilson-Raybould ultimately stuck to her course, no line was crossed, noting that it is not the outcome of the arm-twisting that determines whether it took place.</p><p class="text-block-container">Nor did Dion find merit in the suggestions that the former attorney-general was difficult to work with or that she had given Trudeau cause to doubt she had done due diligence on the file.</p><p class="text-block-container">The ethics commissioner did not even give the prime minister much of the benefit of the doubt for possibly having been abetted by aides overzealous in their efforts to achieve what their boss wanted.</p><p class="text-block-container">On the contrary Dion writes: “As prime minister, Mr. Trudeau was the only public office holder who, by virtue of his position, could clearly exert influence over Ms. Wilson-Raybould.” He adds: “…the evidence abundantly shows that Mr. Trudeau knowingly sought to influence Ms. Wilson-Raybould both directly and through the actions of his agents.”</p><div class="image article-content__image image__has-rightrail pure-image hideRegistration image--flush-sides"><div class="image__body white-background"><img src="https://images.thestar.com/jJ2GhJkmP2Y5pduTbf9FhNXF9tg=/0x0:4349x2970/968x661/smart/filters:cb(1565821009407)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/uploads/2019/08/14/skp104540068-0.jpg" srcset="https://images.thestar.com/jJ2GhJkmP2Y5pduTbf9FhNXF9tg=/0x0:4349x2970/968x661/smart/filters:cb(1565821009407)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/uploads/2019/08/14/skp104540068-0.jpg 968w,https://images.thestar.com/guv4nd2Wm544XpXLMOhrYTD_WPk=/0x0:4349x2970/850x580/smart/filters:cb(1565821009407)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/uploads/2019/08/14/skp104540068-0.jpg 850w,https://images.thestar.com/hoz7_n3cA9gtH8FzkVhX6mlWGX8=/0x0:4349x2970/650x444/smart/filters:cb(1565821009407)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/uploads/2019/08/14/skp104540068-0.jpg 650w,https://images.thestar.com/vk7uHnMpGQRsPV6P2ddFhkhbJUI=/0x0:4349x2970/605x413/smart/filters:cb(1565821009407)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/uploads/2019/08/14/skp104540068-0.jpg 605w,https://images.thestar.com/Wvp208537E4bLNiGzJ1WbJJuNMw=/0x0:4349x2970/480x328/smart/filters:cb(1565821009407)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/uploads/2019/08/14/skp104540068-0.jpg 480w,https://images.thestar.com/822MtI16sJngDNXuF1rKooX3TIU=/0x0:4349x2970/400x273/smart/filters:cb(1565821009407)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/uploads/2019/08/14/skp104540068-0.jpg 400w,https://images.thestar.com/JW5QSM9_e1tQOyiwJhxAv2SpK3Q=/0x0:4349x2970/320x219/smart/filters:cb(1565821009407)/https://www.thestar.com/content/dam/thestar/uploads/2019/08/14/skp104540068-0.jpg 320w" alt="Jody Wilson-Raybould, former Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada, and Jane Philpott, former Minister of Health, are seen leaving the House of Commons in this file photo taken in Ottawa on Thursday, April 13, 2017."/></div><div class="caption-container"><button type="button" class="caption-button alcta" data-alparams="{"ltype":"pageaction","ctype":"expand","label":"caption", "position": "undefined"" aria-label="Show Caption"><i class="staricon show-caption-icon staricon-caption-show"></i></button></div></div><p class="text-block-container">Liberal sources say they had no heads-up about the imminent release of the report. Earlier this week, PMO officials still estimated that the findings would be published in early September.</p><p class="text-block-container">The fact that the report landed sooner rather than later may be the only saving grace for the government in the latest instalment of the saga that has plagued the Liberals since last winter. </p><p class="text-block-container">The closer to the vote the harder it would be to contain the damage of a bombshell of this magnitude.</p><p class="text-block-container">If the <a class="text-block__link" oncontextmenu="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" onclick="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" href="https://www.thestar.com/news/federal-election.html">election</a> were not so close, Trudeau’s future as Liberal leader and prime minister might become a matter for internal debate within his party’s ranks. In other circumstances Dion’s report would amount to putting a big target on the leader’s back.</p><p class="text-block-container">But the proximity of the federal campaign, to be launched officially next month, will almost certainly temper the temptation to look for a possible saviour. It is not as if there is really one in obvious sight.</p><div class="article-related-inline"><div class="c-related-articles" data-lpos="article|related-stories"><h2 class="article-list-heading"><div class="article-list-heading-text article-list-heading-text--small">RELATED STORIES</div></h2><div class="c-related-articles-inline__content"><a class="c-mediacard__content"><div class="c-mediacard-labels c-mediacard__labels"><span class="c-mediacard-labels__label c-mediacard-labels__label--section" data-test-id="label-section">Canada</span></div><h3 class="c-mediacard__heading mediacard-headline__short"><span data-test-id="mediacard-headline">Key quotes from the ethics report on Trudeau</span></h3><div class="c-mediacard-footer"><div class="c-mediacard-footer__items-left"><div class="article__published-date"><span><i class="staricon article__published-date--warning-icon staricon-error-reporting"></i></span><span class="article__published-date article__published-date--warning">Aug. 14, 2019</span></div></div></div></div></a></div></div></div><span style="display:block" id="contentLongBreakPoint"></span><p class="text-block-container">On Wednesday, Trudeau certainly did not sound like a politician who was headed anywhere but on the hustings.</p><p class="text-block-container">In the same breath as he accepted Dion’s report, the prime minister again maintained that he was not about to apologize for having tried to protect Canadian jobs. Expect him to stick to that line going forward. </p><style data-emotion-css="12fm3bw">.css-12fm3bw{border-radius:5px;box-shadow:0 2px 8px 0 rgba(0,0,0,0.08);background-color:#fff;padding:14px 24px Trudeau to disagree with the ethics commissioner on that point will be known, as the prime minister noted, within a matter of months.</p><p class="text-block-container">By all indications, his rivals are also content — at this juncture — to leave it to Canadians to pass judgment in October.</p><p class="text-block-container">Federal Conservative Leader <a class="text-block__link" oncontextmenu="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" onclick="theStarLinkClick(event, this)" href="https://www.thestar.com/topic.andrew_scheer.html">Andrew Scheer </a>had called for Trudeau’s resignation early on in this affair. But on Wednesday, his main message was an invitation to voters to punish the Liberals on election day.</p><span style="display:block" id="contentEndBreakPoint"></span><p class="text-block-container">That Dion inflicted a hit on Trudeau that the opposition parties could only dream of is not in question. It will take a while longer to know whether that makes the Liberal leader a dead man walking.</p><div class="author-endnote-container border-bottom" data-lpos="article|author|bottom"><div>Chantal Hébert is a columnist based in Ottawa covering politics.
